evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 and -4 are used widely in the nuclear industry as cladding and structural material for fuel rods because of good thermal. nuclear, and mechanical properties. as well as good resistance to corrosion

extra_properties.susceptibility: Zr(Cr,Fe)₂ precipitates show greater susceptibility to amorphization under neutron irradiation

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk3

evidence_span: Schematic plot of the dose to amorphization versus temperature for the three types of irradiation

extra_properties.precipitate_comparison: Zr₂(Ni,Fe) vs Zr(Cr,Fe)₂ amorphization susceptibility varies with irradiation type
extra_properties.amorphization_mechanism: competition between athermal damage and thermal recovery processes

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk4
evidence_span: The energy difference G_a is on the order of 0.02 eV/atom

extra_properties.energy_storage: irradiation-induced free energy increase leads to amorphization

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: The critical temperature for amorphization under electron irradiation is ≈300 K (Fig. 11)

extra_properties.amorphization_mechanism: chemical disordering and point defect accumulation

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: The observed Fe depletion would therefore not be a cause of the amorphization, but a result of it. This happens because the Fe in the amorphous precipitate would not be in equilibrium with the matrix [15].

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: Neutron - Chemical disordering caused by cascades supplemented at the precipitate/matrix interface by a departure from stoichiometry caused by ballistic mixing

extra_properties.free_energy_rise: chemical disordering supplemented by departure from stoichiometry
extra_properties.temperature_dependence: increased annealing in cascades close to critical temperature
extra_properties.qualitative_aspects: preferential depletion of Fe from precipitates observed after amorphization

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: Electron - Accumulation of vacancies in the lattice because of interstitial migration to surface. This is supplemented by chemical disordering

extra_properties.free_energy_rise: vacancy accumulation with interstitial migration to surface
extra_properties.temperature_dependence: sustainable vacancy supersaturation is lower near critical temperature
extra_properties.qualitative_aspects: high dose rates facilitate amorphization because vacancy concentration is higher for a given dose

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: Ion - Chemical Disordering caused by cascades

extra_properties.temperature_dependence: long range vacancy reordering activated at critical temperature
extra_properties.qualitative_aspects: inversion of relative precipitate stabilities from high to low temperature could indicate different amorphization mechanisms
extra_properties.critical_temperature: higher than for electrons and lower than for neutrons

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk7
evidence_span: Under electron irradiation and low temperature ion irradiation, no changes in precipitate composition were observed upon amorphization
process_step: electron irradiation, low temperature ion irradiation

extra_properties.amorphization_behavior: no changes in precipitate composition observed upon amorphization

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk7
evidence_span: Under high temperature ion irradiation, no morphological changes were observed, but we did see a depletion in Fe and Cr from the precipitates

extra_properties.composition_changes: depletion in Fe and Cr from precipitates

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk7
evidence_span: neutron irradiated Zircaloy-4 to a fluence of about 9 dpa at a temperature of 300 to 330°C

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_044_chunk8
evidence_span: Pressure tubes that form the primary pressure boundary in CANDU reactors are made of cold worked Zr-2.5Nb autoclaved in steam at 400°C to produce a black adherent oxide film of ~1 to 2 μm in thickness
